quotes: In September 1996, after leaving his cabinet position, Kan helped create the Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ) with Yukio Hatoyama.
In 1998, he took over as the leader of the DPJ after Yukio Hatoyama resigned.
In July 2003, the DPJ and the Liberal Party decided to join together.
In 2004, Kan faced an issue regarding unpaid pension contributions. He resigned as party leader.
In 2005, Kan suggested creating a new political party. He called it the 'Dankai (baby boomer) Party.'
On January 6, 2010, Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama chose Naoto Kan to be the new finance minister.
On June 2, 2010, Yukio Hatoyama announced he would resign as Prime Minister and leader of the DPJ.
Kan then won the leadership election for the DPJ on June 4.
On June 8, Emperor Akihito formally appointed him as the 94th Prime Minister of Japan.
